sense.name: a sudden catastrophe or calamity, widespread
sense.commentary: DISASTER[+event][+catastrophe][+sudden][+widespread] Note: implies physical destruction, affects more than a few individuals
sense.examples: The disaster from the 8.5 earthquake stretched on for miles. They were slow to get disaster relief to the hurricane victims in Florida. John said it was just another stupid disaster movie with pretty good special effects.

sense.name: an ongoing state of adversity or misfortune
sense.commentary: DISASTER[+state][+adversity][+ongoing] Note: implies an abstract calamity, rather than a physical one, e.g., involving money, work
sense.examples: Critics warned that these energy policies could spell disaster for the state. Devaluing their currency by thirty percent caused an economic disaster in that country. We had a disaster at work when someone accidentally erased the backup tapes.

sense.name: a failure, usually on a personal scale
sense.commentary: DISASTER[+quality][+failure][+personal] Note: is a colloquial usage, implies minor calamity in contrast to senses 1 and 2
sense.examples: Betty thinks her haircut is a total disaster. The dinner party was a disaster; the food was overcooked and the guests quarreled. She needs to learn that having people see her house untidy is not such a disaster.
